verses.verse: But Hezekiah (Ps. 116:12) did not repay according to the favor shown him, for (2 Chr. 26:16; (Hab. 2:4)) his heart was lifted up; (2 Chr. 24:18) therefore wrath was looming over him and over Judah and Jerusalem.

(Jer. 26:18, 19) Then Hezekiah humbled himself for the pride of his heart, he and the inhabitants of Jerusalem, so that the wrath of the LORD did not come upon them (2 Kin. 20:19) in the days of Hezekiah.

Hezekiah’s Wealth and Honor Hezekiah had very great riches and honor. And he made himself treasuries for silver, for gold, for precious stones, for spices, for shields, and for all kinds of desirable items;
storehouses for the harvest of grain, wine, and oil; and stalls for all kinds of livestock, and folds for flocks.
Moreover he provided cities for himself, and possessions of flocks and herds in abundance; for (1 Chr. 29:12) God had given him very much property.

(Is. 22:9-11) This same Hezekiah also stopped the water outlet of Upper Gihon, and brought the water by tunnel to the west side of the City of David. Hezekiah (2 Chr. 31:21) prospered in all his works.

However, regarding the ambassadors of the princes of Babylon, whom they (2 Kin. 20:12; Is. 39:1) sent to him to inquire about the wonder that was done in the land, God withdrew from him, in order to ((Deut. 8:2, 16)) test him, that He might know all that was in his heart.

Death of Hezekiah Now the rest of the acts of Hezekiah, and his goodness, indeed they are written in (Is. 36—39) the vision of Isaiah the prophet, the son of Amoz, and in the (2 Kin. 18—20) book of the kings of Judah and Israel.

(1 Kin. 1:21; 2 Kin. 20:21) So Hezekiah rested with his fathers, and they buried him in the upper tombs of the sons of David; and all Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem (Ps. 112:6; Prov. 10:7) honored him at his death. Then Manasseh his son reigned in his place.
Manasseh Reigns in Judah Manasseh (2 Kin. 21:1-9) was twelve years old when he became king, and he reigned fifty-five years in Jerusalem.
But he did evil in the sight of the LORD, according to the ((Deut. 18:9-12); 2 Chr. 28:3; (Jer. 15:4)) abominations of the nations whom the LORD had cast out before the children of Israel.

For he rebuilt the high places which Hezekiah his father had (2 Kin. 18:4; 2 Chr. 30:14; 31:1) broken down; he raised up altars for the Baals, and (Deut. 16:21; 2 Kin. 23:5, 6) made wooden images; and he worshiped (Deut. 17:3) all the host of heaven and served them.
He also built altars in the house of the LORD, of which the LORD had said, (Deut. 12:11; 1 Kin. 8:29; 9:3; 2 Chr. 6:6; 7:16) “In Jerusalem shall My name be forever.”
And he built altars for all the host of heaven (2 Chr. 4:9) in the two courts of the house of the LORD.

((Lev. 18:21); Deut. 18:10; 2 Kin. 23:10; 2 Chr. 28:3; Ezek. 23:37, 39) Also he caused his sons to pass through the fire in the Valley of the Son of Hinnom; he practiced (Deut. 18:11; 2 Kin. 17:17) soothsaying, used witchcraft and sorcery, and ((Lev. 19:31; 20:27); 2 Kin. 21:6) consulted mediums and spiritists. He did much evil in the sight of the LORD, to provoke Him to anger.

(2 Kin. 21:7; 2 Chr. 25:14) He even set a carved image, the idol which he had made, in the house of God, of which God had said to David and to Solomon his son, (Ps. 132:14) “In this house and in Jerusalem, which I have chosen out of all the tribes of Israel, I will put My name forever;

(2 Sam. 7:10) and I will not again remove the foot of Israel from the land which I have appointed for your fathers—only if they are careful to do all that I have commanded them, according to the whole law and the statutes and the ordinances by the hand of Moses.”
So Manasseh seduced Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem to do more evil than the nations whom the LORD had destroyed before the children of Israel.
Manasseh Restored After Repentance And the LORD spoke to Manasseh and his people, but they would not listen.

(Deut. 28:36) Therefore the LORD brought upon them the captains of the army of the king of Assyria, who took Manasseh with hooks, (2 Chr. 36:6; Job 36:8; Ps. 107:10, 11) bound him with bronze fetters, and carried him off to Babylon.
Now when he was in affliction, he implored the LORD his God, and (2 Chr. 7:14; 32:26; (1 Pet. 5:6)) humbled himself greatly before the God of his fathers,

and prayed to Him; and He (1 Chr. 5:20; Ezra 8:23) received his entreaty, heard his supplication, and brought him back to Jerusalem into his kingdom. Then Manasseh (1 Kin. 20:13; Ps. 9:16; Dan. 4:25) knew that the LORD was God.

After this he built a wall outside the City of David on the west side of (1 Kin. 1:33) Gihon, in the valley, as far as the entrance of the Fish Gate; and it (2 Chr. 27:3) enclosed Ophel, and he raised it to a very great height. Then he put military captains in all the fortified cities of Judah.

He took away (2 Chr. 33:3, 5, 7) the foreign gods and the idol from the house of the LORD, and all the altars that he had built in the mount of the house of the LORD and in Jerusalem; and he cast them out of the city.
He also repaired the altar of the LORD, sacrificed peace offerings and (Lev. 7:12) thank offerings on it, and commanded Judah to serve the LORD God of Israel.
